question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2024-04-30 12:30:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/22560). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

Shortly after new Ukrainian mobilization law [was signed](https://edition.cnn.com/2024/04/16/europe/zelensky-signs-mobilization-law-intl-latam/index.html), all [consular services for men age 18-60 was suspended](https://edition.cnn.com/2024/04/23/europe/ukraine-consulates-mobilization-intl-latam/index.html), including issuing and renewing passports.

In light of these developments, there have been concerns, reportedly amplified by [Russian propaganda](https://disinfo.detector.media/en/post/the-ukrainian-government-allegedly-wants-to-cancel-the-international-passports-of-citizens-abroad), that this will be supplemented by revoking already-issued passports, thus forcing Ukrainian men to return home.

question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if, before January 1, 2026, [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) report that the Ukraine government has initiated a policy of revoking previously valid passports of Ukrainian men, deemed to be of draft age, who reside outside the country.

If no credible sources report such revocation before January 1, 2026, this question resolves as **No**.

**Russia Launches Largest Autumn Draft Since 2016**
Russian President Vladimir Putin signed a decree launching a record autumn conscription campaign that will run from Oct. 1 to Dec. 31, 2025. The decree mandates the drafting of men aged 18‑30 who are not in the reserve and whose service terms have expired, and it also authorises the release of soldiers, sailors, sergeants and foremen whose contracts have ended. Slight increases in probability are acknowledged only under scenarios of catastrophic military or political deterioration, where existential desperation could overcome these barriers, but no available credible reporting or government signaling indicates an imminent policy shift. Rumors of mass revocations are heavily amplified by Russian disinformation, not grounded in government announcements or legislative action. Experts consistently describe a 'no' scenario as one of continued and escalating administrative pressure with provision of services denied, while the 'yes' scenario requires an unlikely radical policy pivot triggered by extreme crisis.
